text: Can Turing.jl can perform Bayesian estimation with DAEs? I am trying to use it directly as in the example but am running into issues.

elements.text: Can Turing.jl can perform Bayesian estimation with DAEs? I am trying to use it directly as in the example but am running into issues.

text: It should work. What's your issue?

elements.text: It should work. What's your issue?

text:
I cannot consistently get this error - however when I do it is:
ERROR: LoadError: TaskFailedException:
MethodError: no method matching dae_fn!(::Array{Float64,1}, ::Array{Float64,1}, ::Array{Float64,1}, ::Float64)
Closest candidates are:
  dae_fn!(::Any, ::Any, ::Any, ::Any, ::Any)

When I use the same line outside of the Turing @model it runs fine

text:
On a second note, I am trying to use DABDF2 with the `BrownFullBasicInit` scheme to solve for the algebraic variables, but it doesn't seem to always solve. I need to keep the differential variables constant but in the docs I only see an option of this and Shampine Collocation which would change the DVs.

If I use say, optim, I can solve for the initial point given the problem parameters fine. Within the Turing @model would I be able to do simply include the optimisation problem for the AEs?
